loans.name: Salama Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: William K., who leads this loan group, is happily married, has five children and has made a living as a coffee farmer for the last four years. Coffee is a highly lucrative cash crop that has helped many Ugandans to extricate themselves from poverty. William’s story is typical -- he began his career as a dairy farmer, but soon switched to coffee because it presented greater opportunities. Today, his weekly profits come to about 50,000 Ugandan shillings. Though he is affected by changes in local and international coffee prices, his commitment to his crop has never wavered. He also believes that this prospects are bright, in part because of the revival of coffee-marketing unions in his area. His confidence is also strong because he continues to operate a small diary business, which means he has a diversified income source. He is applying for this loan to buy more coffee seedlings to plant, along with various pieces of equipment he needs to bring his crop to market.

loans.use: To expand several small businesses

loans.name: Nasuuti Womens Group-Mukono

texts.en: A. Janiffer, who leads this loan group, is 41 years old and went into business selling snacks six years ago. She works in Lweza-Mukono with the support of her husband, who strongly supported her decision to go into business. They are the proud parents to six lively and healthy children, all of whom attend school. She supplements her income by raising pigs. She works hard, but is kept going by a strong sense of purpose and determination. She now earns 50,000 Ugandan shillings a week, and plans to use this loan to buy more potatoes, cassava and pigs to sell. She also wants to expand her business by selling chickens as well.

loans.use: To expand several small businesses

loans.name: Batmakan's Group

texts.en:
Batmakan U. is the leader of the group. She is 56 years old and married. She has two sons and two daughters. The older son works in construction in Kazakhstan, the older daughter studies at university, and the others are at school. Batmakan and her husband have been breeding cattle since 1995. In order to make money Batmakan sells milk every day, for which she earns 4000 KGS per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase hay for cattle to feed during the winter season. 

Klara O., 50, is married. She has three children: a son and two daughters. One of her chidlren works in a pharmacy, another is a construction worker, and the third is a student. Klara and her husband have been breeding cattle since 1995 (after the collective farms broke up). She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a calf to increase the number of cattle.

Cholpon U. is the treasurer of the group. She is 29 and married. She has two sons: the first son is at school and the second is not yet.  Cholpon breeds cattle, and her husband works as an artist in an advertisement agency. When he is available, he helps his wife with the cattle. With money received from the loan, Cholpon wants to purchase a foal for breeding. In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle and build a shed.  

Salkynbu B., 54, is married. She has raised two sons: the first son is a soldier and the second works as a security guard. Salkynbu and her husband breed livestock. With money received from the loan, Salkynbu wants to purchase sheep to increase the number of livestock. She plans to purchase hay with the rest of the money. In the future she wants to save some money to contribute to her son’s wedding and try to build a nice house for him.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase hay for cattle

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old single man living with his parents in Lebanon. He has been working as a plumber repairing toilets, faucets, etc., since 2000. In addition, he works on gypsum board decoration. He works on a freelance basis and he also works on private home projects. His father is taking care of the household but the borrower also helps him with the family expenses, home rental, food expenses, etc. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 to add to his work tools because his business is getting bigger and he must be prepared for any new projects. He intends that, with the help of the loan and the new tools, his profit will automatically be increased. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (e.g. blanking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese micro-finance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in micro-finance. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement to its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US$115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please click here.

loans.use: To add to his work tools

loans.name: Nabuti B Womens Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Any market in Africa is a beehive of competitive business activity, with most people, if not all people, selling foods to make some income. Thirty-one year old N. Esther calls to mind the time when she and her mum used to frequent the busy market area in Kame valley-Mukono. She was then still in her early teens, but she bore witness to the business of making money by hook or by crook in a noisy and boisterous environment. At length she embraced her mom’s words encouraging her to join this business in her early 20’s.

It’s now a decade since she joined the market vending business. She primarily sells Irish potatoes, cassava and yams at her stall. Given the large number of people selling these foods, she has had to summon up a lot of hard work and oil up her tongue to persuade customers to buy foods from her. Her customers are mostly the lowest common denominators. In a week, she can make as much as 100,000 shillings and with this loan, she wants to purchase more bags of the aforementioned foods in bulk to resell to her ever increasing customer base. She envisages a situation where she will have more profits with additional sales of these foods.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of food such as Irish potatoes, cassava and yams to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31 year old married woman and mother of 4 young children. She lives in Lebanon.  She has run a successful bakery for over a decade. She produces tasty Lebanese breads and her products are enjoyed by members of her community. This will be her second loan. It is positive to learn that she has indeed increased her productivity and income since taking the first loan. And she was a very punctual client and has actually repaid her loan in full several months early. She is planning to continue expansion of her business in the coming year. Today, she is requesting to borrow $2,000 to increase her purchases, such as flour and foods used for the breads, before the coming holiday in Lebanon. Her income is important to help support her husband and four children.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To increase her purchases of flour and other ingredients for baking.

loans.name: Kiddawalime Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
She took the cue to begin her grocery business in Kyaliwajjala, Mukono, after a pep talk from a close friend twelve years ago. On net weekly profits of 70,000 shillings, 41-year-old N. Resty, a single mother of four, is highly upbeat about the future financial prospects of her business.

With her high self esteem, Resty has brought hard work to bear in her business. She set forth with savings from a now-defunct restaurant business. She also operates a rental and water sales business which helps her supplement the profits from her grocery store business.

With this loan, Resty wants to buy more stock for her business. She principally wants to buy more tomatoes, Irish potatoes, and fresh fruits.

loans.use: To purchase more tomatoes, Irish potatoes, and fresh fruits to sell

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Silvia J. is currently in the business of selling first-class clothes, bedsheets and women's headdresses at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock shoes and saddles to sell.  

Silvia is 43 years old and married to a chief. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by opening a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock shoes and saddles to sell

loans.name: Deen United Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Deen United” group from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is thirty-three-year-old Umar Deen F.. Umar Deen was born in Lunsar, northern Sierra Leone. He is married and has two children. His wife is a businesswoman and one of his children is attending primary school. The other is not of school-going age. Umar Deen F. sells used clothes and has been running this business for ten years now. He will use his share of the loan to buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business

loans.name: Together As One Group

texts.en:
Fatmata K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fatmata was born in Magburaka town, about thirty-five years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple has three children, all of whom are attending secondary schools. For many years now, Fatmata has been selling groundnuts/peanuts.  

Members of the "Together As One" group are applying for a loan of SLL 3,400,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.  Fatmata will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business. She will buy groundnuts/peanuts wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy groundnuts/peanuts wholesale

loans.name: Go Try Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Go Try” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Abu Bakar K. who is pictured in the left. Abu Bakar is age forty; he was born in Magburaka town where he is currently residing together with his wife and five children. His wife is a businesswoman. Three of his children are attending primary school and two are in secondary school. For fifteen years now, Abu has been a motor vehicle driver. He is requesting this loan to enable him to buy spare parts for his vehicle.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his vehicle

loans.name: Christ In Me Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Christ In Me” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Makeni city, in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Ramatu B.. Ramatu is age twenty-eight; she was born in Makeni and is single with two children who are attending primary school. 

For six years now, Ramatu has been selling market food – rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, etc. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy rice, palm oil, Maggi, salt, etc.

loans.name: Sabanoh Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Sabanoh” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is John T. who is pictured on the left. John is fifty years old. He is married and has four children. Two of Mr. T.’s children are attending primary school, one is in secondary school and the other is already grown-up.

For more than five years now, John has been selling plastic bowls, spoon, cups, dishes, etc. With his share of the loan, John will buy plastic bowls, spoons, cups, etc.

loans.use: Buys plastic bowls, spoon, cups, dishes, etc.

loans.name: Best Of All Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Best Of All” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of SLL 1,400,000 each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

Abdulai K. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group. The 40-year-old was born in a place called Sanda and is married to a businesswoman. They have five children: three in secondary school and the rest not of school-going age.

Abdulai sells medicines and has been doing this business for five years now. With the help of this loan, he will buy more medicines to add to his stock.

loans.use: To buy more medicines for his pharmacy

loans.name: Fight For Shameness Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the members of the “Fight For Shameness” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty-business women who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, in order to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 each. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ramda A. who is pictured on the left. 41-year-old Ramda was born in Bo, a city in southern Sierra Leone. She is a widow with three children: two in secondary school and one in college.

For many years now, Ramda has been selling locally dyed clothes (called “gara lappers”) soap, and some market food like salt, oil, pepper, etc. She will use her share of the loan to expand her business by buying more of the above mentioned items in large quantity.

loans.use: To buy more materials for making gara lappers, plus soaps and market food in large quantity

loans.name: Don’T Worry Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the members of the “Don’t Worry” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Kadiatu S. who is pictured on the left. Kadiatu was born in Makeni and is age forty-two. She is married with six children. His husband is a businessman and her children are attending schools: three in secondary school and three in primary school.

For four years now, Kadiatu has been selling gara lappers (locally dyed clothes). With this loan, she will buy more materials for making gara lappers like white cotton cloth, inks, caustic soda, powder, etc., so that she can produce many gara lappers to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy materials like caustic soda, powder, ink, white cotton cloth, etc. for making gara lappers

loans.name: Together As One Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a Kiva partner in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you the members of the “Together As One” group. They are small-scale-business women in Makeni city and are requesting a loan of SLL 1,000,000 each. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and earn better profits.

Kadiatu K. (left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. She is twenty-nine years of age and is married with three children who are attending primary school.

Kadiatu has had eight years of experience in selling drinks, rice, palm-oil, fish, pepper and gari (fast food made from cassava). With the help of her SLL 1,000,000 loan, she will expand her business by buying more of the above-mentioned goods in large quantity to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, rice, palm-oil, fish, pepper and gari to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes K. is currently in the business of selling bags of beans and groundnuts at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock dried fish to sell.  

Agnes is 41 years old and married to a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

loans.use: Stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Jenty

texts.en:
Jenty M.  is currently in the business of selling dried fish, tomatoes and cooking oil. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of onions and Irish potatoes to sell.  

Jenty is 49 years old and widowed. She has seven children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.use: Stock bags of onions and Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Juan

texts.en: Juan S., currently in the business of baking and selling local Sudanese bread (gelabia) at the market, is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour to make more bread to sell.  Juan, 40 years old, is married to a peasant and they have three children, all attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business by stocking dried fish, tomatoes and onions to sell.

loans.use: To stock more baking flour to make more bread to sell

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah D., currently in the business of selling fried fish, bread and tomatoes at the market, is requesting a loan to stock bags of groundnut to make groundnut phase to sell.  Sarah is 39 years old, married to a peasant, and the mother of three children, all attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase bags of groundnut to make groundnut phase to sell

loans.name: Rwakitami Bakyara Women's, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
Operating a produce business has really improved the living conditions of Margret N., a 58-year-old married mother of three children. Formerly in the farming business, for the past nine years Margret has operated a food produce enterprise selling products including beans, millet, sorghum, and maize in Rwentobo, enabling her to earn 400,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

Margret works hard to meet her family responsibilities which include paying the school fees for her children and other necessities with help from her husband. To enlarge the scale of her business, she is requesting a loan to buy a larger stock of goods. This will enable her to increase her sales and live a more sustaining life as she looks to further business expansion and building a store.

loans.use: To purchase a larger stock of goods for resale

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina C. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a restaurant. She is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant.  

Selina is 42 years old and married to a deputy secretary. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant and purchase more chairs and tables.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant

loans.name: Ermina

texts.en:
Ermina I. is currently in the business of selling fish, tomatoes and cabbages at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish to sell. 

Ermina is 33 years old and married to a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for rent.

loans.use: Stock more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Kitondo United Farmers, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
Operating an agricultural farm has been an adventurous and paying business venture for Constance K.. She is aged 48 years and is from Kitondo village, Rukungiri. Being such a determined, energetic and a hardworking lady, she worked tirelessly to start up the poultry business alongside the sale of bananas, which are commonly used to prepare a local dish by customers here in Uganda.

She is so fond of her enterprise, thus is always able to earn 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings (about $682) monthly through doing her daily business transactions both inside and outside Uganda, like transporting her goods to Rwanda. 

This loan is to help her purchase chicken feeds and, furthermore, to expand the project to a large scale. This will help to improve Constance’s yields and production, thus leading to an increase in sales revenue, which will enable her to enjoy a self-sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: Purchase chicken feeds

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina P. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, okra and eggplant and is requesting a loan to stock sweet potatoes and Irish potatoes to sell.

Selina is 49 years old and is widowed. She has seven children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send two of her children to school.

loans.use: To stock sweet potatoes and Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has three school-age children. He owns a car repair shop specialized in bodywork and painting. He repairs all type of cars and his business has been established since 1995. This will be his second loan. He is thankful for the first loan, it helped him increase his profits and he has been very reliable with the repayments. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,500, a larger amount, to purchase car spare parts to give him an advantage in his business operation; he will be able to make his own profits from them instead of buying from a seller. He is working to open a bigger store to trade and sell spare parts. He said that he would like to one day open a commercial center. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (e.g. blanking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement to its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US$115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase car spare parts

loans.name: Lemeloi Ole

texts.en:
Lemeloi has been buying cattle, fattening them, and selling them later at a profit in Naivasha town for the last four years. He is 27 years old, is married to Mayia Ene Terepe, and they have three children.

Lemeloi was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the money to buy more cattle which he will sell in the future at a profit.

Lemeloi also plans to start processing animal skins and hides to sell.

loans.use: To buy more cattle to raise and sell

loans.name: Rwentobo Tukore Women's Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
K. Bujuguri, aged 40, is married with a family of four children.

Bujuguri has been operating a retail shop in Rwentobo trading centre, Ntungamo, for over ten years. There, he trades in a variety of products common for domestic use like sugar, soft drinks like sodas, water, cooking oil, and much more merchandise.

Bujuguri does this business alongside his farming practices that include growing sorghum and millet which are used as food crops in Uganda.

Bujuguri’s main drawback is that he has a limited variety of products in his shop that cannot satisfy his customers’ demand. Therefore, he is looking forward to increase the stock in his business when he gets this loan and also to expand into a wholesale shop. This will help him earn more revenue and sustain his daily life needs and further educate his children.

Bujuguri belongs to a group of members who insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To increase the stock in his business

loans.name: Peter Mburu

texts.en:
Peter has operated his food stall for over 10 years, serving a wide range of clientele from middle to low income earners. He is 39 years old, married to Tabithat Wanjiru and they have 3 children.

Peter was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 2nd loan. He paid his previous loan of KES 35,000 well and on time. He plans to use the cash from this loan to build/open a butchery next to his food stall. Peter also hopes to have a chain of food stalls around the town of Naivasha in the future.

loans.use: To open a butchery next to his food stall

loans.name: Romo Ole

texts.en:
Romo has been rearing cattle for sale in the town of Naivasha for the last 4 years. He is 24 years old, married to Sempare Ene S. and they have three children.

Romo was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to add more cattle to his herd, to be sold later at a profit. Romo also plans to open up a shop for his wife to sell her cereals.

loans.use: To add more cattle to his herd

loans.name: Kontye

texts.en:
Kontoye has been practicing mixed farming in the town of Naivasha for 21 years. She is 50 years old, married to Kiranto Ole Loltuala and they have three children.  

Kontoye was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the cash to buy more sheep and goats, which she will sell later at a profit during the peak season. Kontoye also hopes to open a grocery shop where she will sell vegetables from her farm.

loans.use: To buy sheep and goats to rear and then sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has one young child. He has owned a metal shop in his town, producing doors, windows, tables etc. and also working on different projects. He has been involved in this occupation for the past 15 years. Due to his experience in this occupation, he has gained a good number of customers asking for his services. He works hard because he is the only provider for his wife and child. Today, he is asking to borrow $1200 to purchase metal at good prices. He feels positive about his future work and looks forward to taking on bigger projects in his community.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: purchase metal

loans.name: Kafuro Fish Farmers, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
N. Ahamed, 66 years old, is a peasant farmer who grows food crops such as onions and coffee, owns a banana plantation and normally sells his crops to produce and grocery business dealers. He is very hardworking and ambitious towards owning a big agricultural farm in his home area of Mirariye, Bushenyi. 
 
N. Ahamed has built a strong attribute of determination, with solid hardworking skills; he has developed his 30 year old enterprise into a dependable niche. Since the beginning, he has been earning monthly profits to the tune of 350,000 UGX. With this loan, he hopes to purchase fertilizers to help improve his agricultural farm and also to buy more seedlings for next season. This will improve his yields, hence his sales revenue and he will be able to live a more satisfying life and educate his children as his main goal.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Bedan Nganga

texts.en:
Bedan has run his butcher shop for over three years. He is 39 years old, married to Naomi Wambui and they have five children.  

Bedan was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his third loan. He paid his previous loan of KES 40,000 well and on time. He plans to use this money to open another butchery, also within Naivasha. Bedan hopes to be a major meat supplier around Naivasha in the future, supplying hotels and schools in the town.

loans.use: To open another butchery in town

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old divorced woman from Lebanon. She lives with her parents and 3 siblings and contributes with her brothers to the household expenses. She started her business selling lingerie from her home. Today, she is the proud owner of a lingerie shop. She has been working hard in her store for the past four years. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva's partner Ameen s.a.l. to further diversify her merchandise selection. She hopes that her varied selection of lingerie will continue to generate good profits and enable her to expand her business even further. She expects her productivity and income to increase in the coming year. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in her picture, not indicating her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: to further diversify her merchandise selection

loans.name: Victor Alfredo

texts.es:
Víctor de 30 años, vive en la Primavera de Duran (zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución), junto con su esposa tienen una carnicería. 

Cuando lo liquidaron en el trabajo que tenia Víctor tuvo que ingeniarcelas para tener dinero y poder mantener a su familia, hasta que un tío de el le enseño administrar una carnicería, y hay comenzó a compra carne, y las maquinas fileteadotas. Poco a poco con ayuda de su esposa a podido agrandar su pequeña carnicería. Trabaja desde las 04h00am fileteando carne para que este a tiempo. 

Para agrandar mas su negocio el quiere comprar con el préstamo carnes, chancho, huesos. En el futuro quiere ser distribuidor de carnes al por mayor.
texts.en:
30-year old Victor lives in Primavera de Duran, (a suburban area with a deteriorating ecosystem). He and his wife run a butcher’s shop. When his former job finished, Victor had to think of something else to do so he could support his family. An uncle taught him how to run a butcher’s store and he started to buy meat and the necessary tools to trim the meat. Gradually, with help from his wife, he was able to expand the little butcher’s shop. He starts work at 4am cutting up the meat so that it is ready on time. To further expand his business, Victor wants to buy meat, pork, and bones. In the future he would like to be a wholesale meat distributor.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy meat, pork, and bones

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 33-year-old married man and the father of two young children. He is from Lebanon. He has more than 15 years of experience running a small car repair shop, where he repairs all type of cars. With his loan request of US $1000 from Kiva's partner Ameen s.a.l., he will be able to increase his business' capital. He is looking to diversify his business by purchasing spare car parts to build up his business. He hopes to open a new shop where he can buy and sell spare car parts. His business income is needed to help support his wife and two children, and to pay the considerable school fees.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: purchasing spare car parts

loans.name: Nyakabungo Traders United, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Kaguna A., 36 years old, with a family of 6, has been operating a repair and spare parts store for bicycles and motorcycles in Burambira, Rukungiri for 5 years. With his determination and hard work, he has been able to earn 200,000 UGX on a monthly basis, which he uses to meet his family's daily requirements including buying food and paying tuition fees.

For a long time, A.'s motive has been to set up a spare parts shop as there is a ready market available. This would help him advance his mechanics job and earn more profit since he would have fewer expenses, such as purchasing machines from other people. Therefore, with this loan, A. hopes to buy spokes, sprockets, tires, chains, realms, frames and so on for business expansion.

loans.use: to purchase mechanical items and spare parts

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.es:
La señora Aurelia C. L. tiene 54 años se encuentra casada con el Sr. Braulio Angulo, ambos esposos, viven en la zona de Piñami, provincia de Quillacollo, a 10 km de la ciudad de Cochabamba, en una zona agrícola en la periferia de la ciudad.

La Sr. Aurelia se dedica a la lechería, cuenta con 5 cabezas de ganando en producción, leche cruda que entrega para su pasteurización a la Planta Industrializadora de leche PIL, ubicado a 1 Km de su propiedad. Aurelia además de la producción de leche cruda también se dedica a la agricultura, cosecha choclos (maíz fresco), para comercializarlo.  El Sr. Braulio Angulo sufre de parquin son, por su edad avanzada, enfermedad que le ha impedido colaborar con las actividades del hogar y propias de su actividad, dejando a la Sr. Aurelia sola con todas las tareas, alimentación del ganado, cuidado de  los pastizales, proceso de obtención de la leche cruda, compra de los insumos, y todas las tareas necesarias para el desarrollo de su tarea. Por fortuna en Cochabamba se brindan apoyo por ONG de forma gratuita a las personas que padecen de esta enfermedad, brindándoles ejercicios de fisioterapia, este apoyo les ayuda, pero también deben brindarle tiempo para realizar estos ejercicios. La Sr. Aurelia con todas estas actividades debe tomarse tiempo para llevar a su esposo a las sesiones de fisioterapia todos los días.

La Sra. Aurelia se apersono, solicitando un crédito, para la compra de alimento para su ganado vacuno, aprovechando la oferta de los mismos a precios muy bajos. La Sra. Aurelia sabe que por la edad avanzada que tiene su esposo no podrá recuperarse por completo pero debe agotar todas las posibilidades, y continuar día a día con la lucha contra esta enfermedad.
texts.en:
Señora Aurelia C. L. is 54 years old and married to Sr. Braulio Angulo. They live in the area of Piñami, in the province of Quillacollo, 10 km from the city of Cochabamba in an agricultural area on the edge of the city. Aurelia raises cows for milk. She has five cows producing milk which she takes to be pasteurized to PIL (Planta Industrializadora de Leche), located about one kilometre from her property. As well as dairy farming, she also grows maize (corn) for sale. Her elderly husband Sr. Braulio suffers from Parkinson's, which has prevented him from helping with household duties, leaving Aurelia to do all the chores alone such as feeding the cows, looking after the pasture, milking the cows, buying supplies, and all the other necessary jobs that go along with her work. Fortunately there is an NGO in Cochabamba that provides free assistance, such as physiotherapy, to people with this disease. This support is a help to them but they have to find the time to do the exercises. Amongst all her other chores, Aurelia has to take her husband to physiotherapy every day. She is asking for a loan to buy food for the cows wishing to take advantage of the current low prices. While she knows that her husband will not recover completely because of his age, she must exhaust all possibilities and continue the daily struggle against this illness.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy food for her cows

loans.name: Philip Maree

texts.en:
Philip currently operates a motorcycle transport business in the town of Naivasha. He has been in this field for over four years. He is 29 years old, married to Mary Keya, and has one child.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend, and this will be his third loan. He repaid his previous loan of 50,000 KES in full and on time. He plans to use the proceeds from the loan to open a grocery store in his neighborhood, which will be managed by his wife.

He hopes to grow this business and improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To open a grocery store.

loans.name: Andella

texts.en:
Hard-working Andella M. runs a retail shop in the Kagongi Trading Centre, where she sells general merchandise. Her store has been in operation for over 10 years. She is a married mother of five children. Recently, she has been having problems restocking her merchandise because the stock is not self-sustaining for the customers.

Therefore, Andella is seeking a loan to help her buy more goods for her business. She hopes that the profit will help her earn a greater income and be in a better position to cater for her family's needs.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her business like sugar, salt, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and three siblings. He has has been running a painting business for the past 15 years. He has been working independently since 2002. He started his business with small projects, and then his work developed from there over the years. He cooperates with all of his family members to satisfy the household expenses. Today, he is requesting a loan for US$1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase painting tools for a new building project. He is positive that this new project will open new opportunities for him. He hopes that in the future he will be able to open a formA. painting store in order to expand his business.

Note: Based on the politicA. and sociA. challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:

Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a microcredit program created by CHF InternationA., Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the CentrA. Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financiA. institution specializing in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financiA. services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use the interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financiA. services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US$115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115.

loans.use: To purchase new painting tools.

loans.name: Katungamo Women's Voice Group

texts.en:
It has now been 22 years since Vincent K. started up his farming business adventure in Ntungamo. The married father of five children is very aggressive and determined when it comes to lucrative business. He has since engaged himself in various farming practices, including livestock, which is his main source of livelihood along with growing and selling bananas and coffee. 

His main drawbacks include bad weather conditions and drought, which reduce the rate of production in terms of milk since animals lack water and grass to feed on, and also fluctuating prices. With this loan, he is looking forward to purchasing more cattle to fatten and sell off at profit. 

Vincent is very optimistic about getting more harvests and more sales revenue and thus be able to look after his family and pay for his children’s education.

loans.use: Buying more livestock, like cattle, for fattening

loans.name: Betty Patricia

texts.es:
Betty de 41 años, ella tiene un salón de belleza en la parte delantera de su casa, vive en las Orquídeas de Guayaquil (zona urbana,  llamada las orquídeas porque en su descubrimiento habían muchas flores orquídeas). 

Betty comenzó cortando cabello y pintando uñas en su casa, hasta que pudo reunir dinero para comprar los utensilios de que necesitaba para su salón de belleza, poco a poco y con la ayuda de su esposo pudo readecuar su casa para ubicar su negocio. Ahora trabaja desde las 14h00pm hasta las 22h00pm todos días. 

Para poder agrandar su negocio ella necesita comprar con el préstamo muebles para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener mejor amoblado su salón de belleza y así asegurar el futuro de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Betty is 41 years old and has a beauty salon in the front part of her house. She lives in Orquídeas de Guayaquil (an urban area named after the many orchids that existed when the place was discovered).

Betty began cutting hair and painting nails from her home in order to earn money to buy equipment she needed for her beauty salon. Little by little and with the help of her husband, she was able to remodel her house so that she could fit in her business. Now she works every day from 2pm to 10pm.

In order to expand her business, she needs a loan to buy furniture. In the future, she wants to have better beauty salon furniture and be able to secure her children’s future.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase furniture for her beauty salon

loans.name: La Inmaculada Concepcion Group

texts.es:
L. INMACULADA CONCEPCION
Feliciana tiene 36 años que vive en L. zona D. Huaycán, es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos que aun dependen D. elL., ya lleva 5 años desD. que puso  su Bodega, es el mismo tiempo que tiene trabajando con L. ayuda D. EDAPROSPO  y aunque al principio solo vendía gaseosas, ahora también venD. productos alimenticios como  aceites, leche, menestras y  fideos, además D. productos D. belleza. Con L. ayuda D. este negocio y L. D. su conviviente que trabaja en construcción, sustenta los alimentos del hogar y los estudios D. sus hijos. Está muy contenta D. formar este equipo llamado: “L. Inmaculada Concepción” que se formo a partir D. L. amistad con sus vecinas. ElL. espera agrandar su negocio, llenar más su tienda y ayudar a sus amigas a que también desarrollen su negocio.
texts.en:
THE IMMACULATE CONCEPTION Feliciana is 36 years old and lives in the district of Huaycán. She is in a common law marriage and has three children who are dependent on her. For the past five years she has managed a grocery store. During this time she has worked with the help of EDAPROSPO. Although she only sold soft drinks at first, Feliciana now sells food products such as cooking oil, milk, soups, and noodles, as well as beauty products. Through this business and with the support of her partner, who works in construction, she is able to proviD. for the daily household needs and pay for her children’s education. She is very happy with her Communal Bank team called “L. Inmaculada Concepción” (The Immaculate Conception), which was formed out of the friendship she has with her neighbors. Feliciana hopes to expand her business, fill her store with more merchandise, and help her friends who also want to develop their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise & supplies

loans.name: Yolanda Monica

texts.es:
Yolanda de 48 años, , vive en la Primavera de Duran (zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución), ella trabaja en su carro haciendo taxi y expreso todos los días. 

Cuando llego a vivir a Duran comenzó a trabajar en su carro para tener dinero adicional para sus hijos, trabajaba haciéndoles expresos a sus vecinas pero como ya comenzaba la época escolar decidió hacer expreso a los niños de una escuela. Desde ese tiempo hasta ahora ha venido trabajando desde las 06h000am hasta las 17h00pm. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar repuestos para su carro, en el futuro quiere comprar una furgoneta para convertirlo en un expreso grande, y así asegurar el futuro de sus 4 hijos.
texts.en:
Yolanda is 48 years old and lives in the Primavera de Duran (a semi-urban zone with a deteriorating ecosystem). She works in her car, providing taxi and chauffeur service every day. When she moved to Duran, she started to work from her car in order to make extra money for her children. She worked providing rides to her neighbors, but when the school year started, she decided to transport children from school. Since that time, she has been working from 6:00 AM to 5:00 PM. She will use the requested loan to buy spare parts for her car. She wants to buy a van in the future, to expand her business and thereby ensure the future of her four children.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Spare parts

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia, D. 53 años D. edad, está casada y tiene tres hijos, Yanet, Letner y Brechman D. 20,18 y 17 años. Juntos residen en la localidad D. Santa Rosa, ubicada en la hermosa selva ayacuchana, donD. tiene su propia casa. Para Antonia, “la clave del éxito D. una persona radica en el trabajo constante y el saber aprovechar las oportunidades”; es por ello que tiene esa tranquilidad mesurada, no se nubla por nada del mundo, ya que ella reconoce que el mundo es cambiante y para ello siempre trata D. estar preparada ante cualquier evento que se le presente. Hoy su producto es reconocido en su localidad, esto es debido a la calidad y al buen servicio que trata a cada uno D. sus clientes, desD. luego que percibe buenas ganancias económicas. Usualmente trabaja con su familia, y juntos hacen un buen equipo D. trabajo, solo que en temporada D. cosecha tienen a cargo D. sus peones para que lo pueda facilitar la extracción D. su producto y venderlo en los centros D. acopio D. su localidad a un precio competitivo. Sus planes a futuro es abrir un negocio D. abarrotes con el propósito aumentar sus ganancias. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, por el cual segura cumplir fielmente con su cronograma D. pagos, además se siente contenta con su banco comunal, ya que todos se solidarizan entre sí.
Con el crédito que solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra D. cacao D. otros productores, con la finalidad D. que pueda cumplir la demanda que tiene.
texts.en:
Antonia, 53 years old, is married and has 3 children: Yanet (20), Letner (18) and Brechman (17). They live in the Santa Rosa locality, located in the beautiful Ayacuchan jungle, where Antonia has her own house. For Antonia 'the key to success lies in constant work and the knowledge to take advantage of opportunities'. Because of this outlook Antonia has a measured calmness and nothing throws her, as she recognises that the world is changeable and she tries to be prepared for whatever event presents itself. Antonia's product is well-known in her locality, owing to the quality and good service she provides to each and every customer, and for a long time she has maD. good profits. Usually Antonia works with her family and together they make a good working team - only during harvest time do they have to contract agricultural labourers to extract their product and sell it in the stock centres in her zone at a competitive price. Antonia's future plans are to open a grocery store with the view to increasing her earnings. This is her first loan with MFP and she promises to faithfully comply with the repayment timeline. Antonia is happy with her communal bank as everyone supports each other. With this loan Antonia will invest in purchasing cocoa from other producers so she can meet the demand she has.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cocoa to meet demand

loans.name: Josefina

texts.es:
La Sra. Josefina S. R. es soltera, tiene 49 años vive por la zona de Esquilan Chico, a 10 km de la Ciudad de Cochabamba, zona agrícola, en la periferia de la ciudad. 

Cuenta con 5 cabezas de ganado lechero de las cuales, la producción de leche cruda las comercializa en la Planta Industrializadora de Leche PIL. La Sra. Josefina, es soltera solo tiene a su sobrina, a quien cuida, viven solas, no cuentan con las mejores condiciones de vida, pues sus paredes son de calaminas, y soportan las inclemencias del tiempo, frio, lluvias y calor; incluso su ganado apenas tiene un techo de paja conde se protegen. Bajo estas condiciones logra sustentar a su sobrina la cual está estudiando en el colegio. Y el deseo de la Sra. Josefina es que sobrina estudie veterinaria y puedan juntas mejorar su calidad de vida, su vivienda, y sus ingresos.

La Sra. Josefina solicito un crédito para la construcción de comederos para su ganado de modo así pueda, optimizar la alimentación de su ganado vacuno e incrementar sus ingresos. Al construir su comedero para ganado evitara que estos se enfermen, a demás que se eche a perder al alimento que consumen, estaría ahorrando e invirtiendo en algo muy productivo que le dará frutos favorables.
texts.en:
Josefina S. R. is single and is 49 years old. She lives in the Esquilan Chico zone, 10km from Cochabamba city, in an agricultural zone on the periphery of the city. Josefina has 5 head of dairy cattle who produce raw milk which is commercialised in the Industrial Milk Plant (PIL). Josefina is single but looks after her niece. They live alone and don't have very good living conditions - their walls are made from corrugated iron which has to withstand the inclemencies of the weather, cold, rain and heat. Her cattle have a thatched roof to protect them. Under these conditions Josefina manages to look after her niece, who is studying at school. Josefina's wishes are that her niece studies veterinary science and that together they can improve their quality of life, her home, and her earnings. Josefina is seeking a loan to build feeding troughs for her cattle so she can optimise their feeding and increase her earnings. By constructing feeding troughs she will avoid them getting sick, and apart from preventing her throwing away the food they eat, she would be saving and investing in something very productive that will be fruitful for her.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase feeding troughs to feed cattle

loans.name: La Esperanza Del Futuro Group

texts.es:
La señora Martha Domínguez Sánchez tiene treinta y ocho  años, vive en la ribera de Benito Juárez está casada con el señor Jenaro Sánchez Alegría y con quien procreo tres hijos varones, pablo con veintiuno de edad, Luis  miguel con dieciséis años en tercero de secundaria y el más chico Abel de doce años que está por entrar en sexto en la primaria y quiere ser ingeniero agrónomo.

  Ella se dedica a  su hogar y a la elaboración de quesos, cremas y quesillos, comenzó con esta actividad hace dos años, donde compra la leche para cuajarla a si elaborar su producto. Comenta que con esta actividad a salido a delante pues es una actividad de buen resultado y se vende muy bien  ya que hay personas que le compra por encargo para revenderlo en otro municipios a un a si también las personas de su ribera le compran por ser un queso rico de buen precio,  buena calidad y en buena ubicación.

  Su motivo a realizar esta actividad es su familia ya que también quiere aportar con los ingresos de la casa, ya que su esposo también trabaja en el campo sembrando milpas y frijol para su servicio y para vender.

  Con las ganancias que obtiene de los quesos compra mas leche para elaborar sus quesos  de eso mismo a horrar para a poyar a sus hijos a que terminen su carrera que tanto desea en la vida y así trabajen para que juntos construyan una quesería amplia para guardar los quesos ya laborados.

  Paso a formar parte del grupo por la invitación de su vecina la señora María Deysi que le platico del programa en el cual hoy es representante. El grupo se llama  la esperanza del futuro la razón del nombre es porque tienen la esperanza de que con el préstamo trabajen y salgan adelante.

Las personas que integran el grupo la esperanza del futuro son: 
	
  María Aurora Sánchez M.: invierte el préstamo para comprar más mercancía para la elaboración de panes.
  Beroisa Sánchez Alegría: invierte el préstamo en la compra de res y luego venderlo destazado.
 María Deysi Mejía S.: invierte el préstamo en la compra y venta de ganados de ganados porcinos para    venderlo a si también elabora tacos fritos para venderlo en la comunidad.
 Marbella Ramírez López: invierte en la compra de dulces de caramelo para venderlo cerca de la escuela.
texts.en:
Mrs. Martha Domínguez Sánchez, 38, lives in Benito Juárez and is married to Mr. Jenaro Sánchez Alegría. They have three sons: Pablo, 21, Luis Miguel, 16, in 9th grade, and Abel, the youngest, 12, who is about to start 6th grade and wants to become an Agronomist. She is a housewife but also makes cheese, cream and cottage cheese. She started this business two years ago. She buys milk to curdle and thus make her products. She comments that this activity has made it possible for her to get ahead because it is a profitable business that sells well because there are many persons who order from her in order to resell in other municipalities in the region; she also sells directly to residents of her area who buy from her because it’s delicious, good quality, well priced, locally available cheese. She was motivated to go into this work because she wanted to contribute to household income since her husband also works as a corn and bean farmer both for their own consumption and to sell. Profits from the cheese sales are used to buy more milk to make more cheese and are saved to help support the children’s pursuit of their careers, something she wishes with all her heart and that together they build a large cheese factory where they can store the cheeses they make. She became a member of the group thanks to the invitation from Mrs. María Deysi who spoke about the program she represents. The group is called “Esperanza del Futuro” (Hope for the Future). The reason behind the name is that they have the hope that with help from the funds they will work and succeed. The other members of Hope for the Future are: María Aurora Sánchez M.: to buy bread baking ingredients. Beroisa Sánchez Alegría: to buy beef to butcher and sell. María Deysi Mejía S.: to buy pigs to sell and also to make fried tacos to sell in the community. Marbella Ramírez López: to buy candy to sell near the school.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk for cheese making.

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es: Bertha, de 39 años de edad, está casada y tiene 5 hijos en etapa escolar. Juntos residen en la localidad de Santa Rosa, ubicada en la selva tropical peruana, donde tiene su techo propio a base de adobe. Bertha no se desanima por no tener estudios inconclusos, es mas, fue motivo para que saque fuerzas y voluntad como toda mujer luchadora, ante obstáculos que se les pueda presentar. Fruto del esfuerzo constante, pudo tener un negocio en donde le da buenos resultados económicos, ya que cultiva y comercializa cacao, por el cual sus clientes se sienten satisfecho por la calidad de su producto. De todas maneras quiere seguir apostando en la actividad agrícola, ya que se siente feliz con lo que viene realizando, para ello recibe la ayuda de sus hijos en temporada de cultivo y cosecha, pero permanentemente trabaja con su querido esposo de lunes a sábado, a partir de las 7:00 de la mañana hasta las 6:00 de la tarde y su punto de venta lo realiza en los centros de acopio de su localidad a un precio justo. Su plan a futuro es diversificar de productos cultivando café y frutas cítricas, para que de esa manera aumente sus ingresos económicos. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, por el cual asegura cumplir fielmente con sus obligaciones de pago, además se siente fortalecido con su banco comunal, ya que todos trabajan en equipo. Con el crédito que solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de insumos y abonos, con la finalidad de que le dé un mantenimiento adecuado a sus plantaciones de cacao.
texts.en:
Bertha is 39 years old, married, and has 5 school-age children. They live together in the community of Santa Rosa, located in the tropical Peruvian rainforest, where they have their own home made of adobe. Bertha has not been discouraged by the fact that she did not finish her studies. Rather, this motivated her to gather her strength and will as a fighting woman, in order to face any obstacles that she encounters. As a result of her constant efforts, she has been able to develop a business that has good economic results. She grows and sells cocoa, and her customers feel satisfied with the quality of her product. She wants to continue working in agriculture, as she feels happy with the work she is doing. She receives help from her children during the planting and harvesting seasons, and she always works with her beloved husband. They both work from 7:00 in the morning until 6:00 in the evening, and they make their sales for a fair price at the local gathering center. Her future plan is to diversify her products by growing coffee and citrus fruits, and in this way, to increase her income. This is her third loan with Microfinanzas Prisma, and she assures that she will comply faithfully with her repayment obligations. She also feels strengthened by her communal bank because they all work as a team. With the loan she is requesting, she plans to invest in the purchase of supplies and fertilizers, with the goal of adequately caring for her cocoa fields.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy bags of fertilizer

loans.name: Sonata De Invierno Group

texts.es:
Evarista participa como tesorera en EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD, en la ALCANCIA COMUNAL SONATA D. INVIERNO, mujer emprendedora cuenta con un negocio independiente, se dedica a realizar trabajos D. tejidos con lana e hilos, elabora gorras, ponchos, conjuntos para bebes y niños, estos trabajos son exportados al extranjero por una empresa que contrata sus servicios, lleva 05 años en este trabajo. Evarista comenzó este oficio por recomendación D. una amiga quien la animó a emprender este pequeño negocio, así mismo se dedica a confeccionar carteras a macramé, que son muy reconocidas por personas e instituciones por su distinguido trabajo;  
Gracias a su esfuerzo a logrado darles una mejor educación a sus hijos, y las comodidades que se requiere, Actualmente sus gastos son afrontados conjuntamente con su esposo para pagar su deuda, está realizando arreglos en su casa para lograr tener un ingreso por alquileres y mejorar su economia. Está contenta con el crédito que ha logrado, porque asi podrà hacer realidad sus planes.
texts.en:
Evarista is the treasurer of the Sonata D. Invierno (Winter Sonata) Communal Bank in EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD. She is an enterprising woman who has an independent business. She makes woven items with wool and thread. She makes hats, ponchos, and outfits for babies and children. Her work is exported to foreign countries by a business that contracts her services. She has been doing this work for five years. Evarista started this craft because a friend recommended it and motivated her to start this small business. She also makes macrame purses, which are very well-known by people and institutions for her distinguished work. Thanks to her effort she has managed to give her children a better education and the necessary comforts. Currently she and her husband tackle their expenses together in order to pay their debt. She is making arrangements in her house to be able to have an income from renters. This is to improve her finances. She is happy with the loan because this is the way she will be able to make her plans a reality.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wool and thread for textiles

loans.name: Las Gardenias Group

texts.es:
La señora María de Lurdes A. A. vive en la Ribera Morelia municipio de Coapilla, Estado de Chiapas México, está casada con el señor Jais Vaquerizo Patricio en el cual procrearon cinco hijos cuatro mujeres y un varón quienes dos de ella ya están casadas y tres aun a  su responsabilidad: Baltzaretti de quince años, Marco Antonio en sexto de primaria y la más pequeña estrella Yuriana de cuatro años, Maria de Lourdes está muy orgullosa de sus hijos.

   Ella se dedica a su hogar y a la venta de dulces típicos de la región  como son: dulce de muégados, coco y dulce de leche, así como también la venta de tamales de bola y de mole. En donde lleva practicando hace cuatro años, y solicito el préstamo para comprar ingredientes para elaborar cada una de sus actividades ya que es donde obtiene ingresos para cubrir gastos pequeños de su hogar.

   La que lo motivo a realizar esta actividad fueros sus dos hijas mayores  quienes  le platicaron que es un buen negocio en donde se obtiene buenos resultados, así comenzó con esta actividad en donde le va muy bien ya que no hay necesidad de salir a venderlo fuera de su ribera pues hay personas que lo compra por encargo y  lo que queda lo sale a vender en las casas cercanas de su domicilio. A un a si su esposo la apoya con los ingresos de su hogar trabajando fuera de su pueblo para que juntos salgan adelante con su familia.
   Con las ganancias que obtiene de su venta de dulces y tamales compra más ingredientes para seguir elaborando su actividad, como también  ahorrar para construir una casita con sus respectivos cuartos para sus hijos y cada uno tenga donde dormir.
    Lourdes formo parte del grupo por sus dos compañeras, quienes la invitaron para unirse con ellas en donde está muy contenta por ser personas responsables, el grupo se llama las gardenias la razón del nombre es porque en casa de una de las integrantes tiene flores con ese nombre.
 Las personas que integran el grupo las gardenias son las siguientes:
  María Mercedes Pérez López: invierte el préstamo para comprar ingredientes como son: huevo, harina, leche, azúcar entre otros para la elaboración de postres como son: flanes, gelatinas, y donas, entre otros.
  Juana Sánchez Saraos: invierte el préstamo en de pósito de refresco.
 María  de Lourdes A. A.: es la señora que se le tomo la entrevista invierte el préstamo en la venta de antojitos como son; dulces típicos de la región y tamales de bola y hoja.
texts.en:
María de Lourdes A. A. lives in Ribera Morelia a municipaility of Coapilla, in the Chiapas State of Mexico. She is married to Jais Vaquerizo Patricio, they have five children - four girls and a boy, two of the girls are already married and three are still their responsibility: Baltzaretti who is fifteen, Marco Antonio in sixth grade at elementary and the youngest Yuriana who is four, Maria de Lourdes is very proud of her children. She looks after the home and sells sweets that are typical of the region such as: "dulce de muégados", coconut and sweet milk, as well as selling "tamales de bola" and "de mole". She has been doing this for four years, and asked for the loan to buy ingredients for each one of her activities since this is where she earns the income to cover the small household expenses. What motivated her to start this business were her two oldest daughters who told her that this was a good business in which she would obtain good results, so she started this business and since it is going very well there is no need to go out selling outside of Ribera as there are people who buy it to order and what remains she goes out to sell to the houses near her own. Her husband helps her with the household income working outside their town so that together they can get their family ahead. With the profits that she obtains from the sale of sweets and tamales she buys more ingredients to continue making them, and also to save to build a little house with respective bedrooms for her children for each one to sleep in. Lourdes formed part of the group with her two partners, who invited her to join with them and they are very happy as they are responsible people. The group is called the "Gardenias" the reason for the name is because at the home of one of the members are flowers with this name. The people that make up the "Gardenias" group are the following: María Mercedes Pérez López: who is investing the loan purchasing ingredients such as: eggs, flour, milk, sugar etc for making desserts like: caramel custards, jellis, and donuts, among others. Juana Sánchez Saraos: who will invest the loan in a refreshments cooperative. María de Lourdes A. A.: is the women interviewed who will invest the loan in selling snacks such as; sweets typical of the region and tamales de bola and hoja.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make snacks, like sweets and tamales.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es: Cecilia, de 53 años de edad, está casada y tiene dos hijos mayores, por el cual lo apoyan económicamente. Vive en la localidad de Santa Rosa (selva central peruana), donde tiene su propia casa. Hace muchos años atrás trabaja en la actividad agrícola, pero no se sentía cómodo con la labor que hacía, ya que a ella siempre le gusto tener su propia tienda, desde luego que lo consiguió con el pasar de los años y con algunos ahorros que tuvo durante su antiguo trabajo. Hoy tiene muchos clientes, lo cual hace que sus ventas son muy satisfactorias, debido al buen servicio que les brinda. Desde entonces la venta de golosinas, galletas y gaseosas ha mejorado con respecto al año anterior, debido a que procura siempre mantener su tienda bien surtida de productos. Su punto de venta lo realiza en su propio barrio, desde las 6:00 de la mañana hasta las 9:00 de la noche y sus planes a futuro es ampliar su negocio, introduciendo nuevos productos de primera necesidad para el hogar, para que así en un tiempo corto se transforme en un bazar. Este es su decimocuarto crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a cumplir con sus respectivos pagos, además está satisfecho con su banco comunal, debido al buen desempeño de cada uno de sus socios. Con el crédito que solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de mercadería, de esa manera pueda abastecer su negocio.
texts.en:
Cecilia is 53 years old, married and lives with her two oldest sons who help support her financially. She lives in the Santa Rosa area (the central Peruvian jungle), where she has her own home. Years ago she worked in agriculture, but she did not feel comfortable doing the work and she always liked having her own store. Over time, and with the money she had saved from her previous work, she was able to establish it. She now has many customers, and her sales are very satisfactory, given the good service that she provides. Since then her sale of sweets, cookies, and soft drinks has improved over the previous year, because she always tries to keep her store well stocked. Her point of sale is in her own neighborhood, and she works from 6:00 am to 9:00 pm. Her future plans are to expand her business by introducing new primary need products for the home, so that she can convert the store into a bazaar in a short time. This will be her 14th loan through MFP, and she is committed to making all of her payments. She is very happy with her communal bank because of the good performance from each of her fellow members. She will use the money from this loan to buy merchandise so that she can supply her business.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Ana Andrea

texts.es: Andrea tiene 57 años de edad vende en el mercado municipal de San Martín Jilotepeque, todos los días trabaja, se dedica a la venta de comida, y en su casa tiene crianza de cerdos. Ella solicita el crédito para comprar cerdos,  alimento para sus animales y maíz. Su sueño es ampliar su venta de comida y tener un local donde vender, ya que por el momento vende en la plaza del mercado municipal. Agradece a FAPE / KIVA por el apoyo que le estan brindando para poder realizar su sueño.
texts.en:
Andrea is 57 year-old trader working in the municipal market of San Martín Jilotepeque. She sells meals there every day, and at home she breeds pigs. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy pigs, animal feed and maize. She dreams of increasing her meals sales and to have a vending stall, as right now she sells her products in the square of the municipal market. She is thankful to FAPE and KIVA for the support they are providing, as this will help her making her dreams come true.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her activity.

loans.name: Delfina

texts.es: Delfina, de 28 años de edad, es casada y tiene dos hijos en etapa escolar. Juntos residen en la localidad de Santa Rosa, ubicada en la hermosa selva ayacuchana, donde tiene su propia casa a base de madera. Delfina asegura que, “no es seguro trabajar como dependiente, sino haciéndolo de forma independiente” desde luego que luchó con mucho sudor y ahínco para lograr lo que tanto había deseado, vale decir, a cultivar y comercializar cacao. Puesto que en anteriores oportunidades trabaja para su familia, cultivando cacao y café, en donde le otorgaban un pago considerable, pero con el tiempo decidió incursionar en la actividad agrícola, por el cual lo está yendo de la mejora manera, incluso cada año va aumentando en su producción de cacao, en donde le dá facilidad para que pueda abastecer a sus compradores y de esa forma mejorar su margen de ganancia. Por lo general trabaja conjuntamente con su esposo, pero de todas maneras necesitan de sus peones en temporada de cosecha, para que extraigan y trasladen el producto final hacia los centros de acopio de su localidad, y luego venderlos a un precio razonable. Sus planes a futuro es seguir ampliando su producción, para ello necesitará comprar nuevos terrenos de cultivos, por consiguiente ofrecer un mejor servicio hacia sus clientes. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con su cronograma de pagos, además se siente conforme con las buenas decisiones que se llegan a determinar en su banco comunal. Con el crédito que solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de insumos y abonos, para que de esa forma pueda darle un mantenimiento permanente a sus plantaciones de cacao.
texts.en:
Delfina is 28 years old, married and has two school aged children. They live together in Santa Rosa, which is located in the beautiful Ayacuchana jungle, where they have their own wood framed house. Delfina is certain that “depending on others for work does not provide security; working independently does.” She’s given much eagerness and perspiration to achieve what she desired; the raising and selling of cacao. She used to work for her family, raising cacao and coffee, where they paid her well for her efforts, but over time she decided to become involved in agriculture herself, which has been going well for her. Each year her cacao production has been increasing, allowing her to supply her buyers and increase her profits. She generally works together with her husband, but she still needs to hire temporary labor to harvest the crop and transport it to the collection center within her locality. There she can then sell it for reasonable prices. Her future plans are to continue to expand production, for which she needs to buy new farmland, and be able to offer better service to her customers. This will be her first loan through MFP, and she is committed to making her payments on schedule. She also feels satisfied with the good decisions that are reached by her communal bank. She plans to use the money from this loan to invest in supplies and fertilizer so that she can permanently maintain her cacao plantations.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Farming supplies and fertilizer

loans.name: Edith

texts.es: Edith, de 26 años de edad, convive con su pareja y fruto de ellos tienen dos  hijos, Renzo y Madeleine, de 8 y 2 años respectivamente. Juntos viven en la hermosa selva ayacuchana, ubicada en la localidad de Santa Rosa, donde tienen su propia casa. Edith es una persona empeñosa y trabajadora, ya que desde muy joven empezó a trabajar  en la chacra de sus familiares, cultivando cacao y café, con el tiempo se dio cuenta de que quería enrumbar por nuevos horizontes. En el presente tiene su propio negocio, que es una tienda y cuenta con un número de clientes que van a su establecimiento, debido a la cordialidad y el precio justo que ofrece.
