He has been engaged in his business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Arnold joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Arnold is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his 8th from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Javzmaa

texts.en:
Javzmaa S. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband works as a policeman while their elder two children attend a local middle school.

Javzmaa operates a children's clothing retail business from a stall at Narantuul-a, the biggest and most crowded market in her town. She sells a variety of different clothing items and accessories and her wide product selection attracts many customers.

Javzmaa started her children's clothing business in 2003. After finding success and achieving stable business operations, she expanded her product line to import women’s clothing from Ereen, a city on the border with China. This product expansion has proved to be a very profitable decision. Today, she is able to hire a salesperson who helps with her business.

Javzmaa is a very open-minded and sociable woman and is well-known to her customers. For the future, she says, "I would like to save money for my sons’ future, because I really like the creating savings". She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more children's and women's clothing items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more children's and women's clothing items for her business

loans.name: Jesus

texts.en: Jesus C. is from the village of Manaoag. He is 50 years old and is married with four adult children. Jesus owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty-four years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Jesus joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Jesus is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his 6th from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Samorn

texts.en:
In the past, Mrs. Samorn M. used to be a silk weaver but she quit her loom because her business was not doing well. Now, she assists her husband in his farming business. They grow different kinds of vegetables such as corn, tomatoes and green beans on their farm in the village.

Besides the farming business, Samorn’s husband is a house builder as well. Currently, he does not have enough materials to complete work on time. Hence Samorn is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase a construction crane for her husband’s house-construction business.

loans.use: To buy a construction crane for her husband’s house-construction business

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia D. is from the village of Bacnor East. She is 58 years old and is married with eight adult children. Virginia owns and operates a business planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Virginia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This loan will be her 8th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Elma

texts.en: Elma F. is from the village of Carugmanan, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 34 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Elma owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Elma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and three siblings, two of whom are still unemployed. In order to help with his family’s expenses, he has opened a barber shop near to his home. The business has been established since 2007 and he has six years of experience in this occupation. Despite his young age, the borrower is very supportive of his father, who works as a farmer, and he helps him with the household expenses. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. so as to be able to expand his business by adding new services and purchasing more equipment. He will also be able to attract new clients. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (e.g. blanking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese micro-finance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in micro-finance. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement to its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US$115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please click here.

loans.use: To add new services and purchase more equipment

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en: Florentina C. is from the village of Bacnor East. She is 57 years old and is married with five adult children. Florentina owns and operates a business tending a canteen near the school. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Florentina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Florentina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Sothea

texts.en:
Mr. Sothea T. (in the photo), is 31 years old and his wife, Mrs. Malini Len, is 29 years old. They have been married since 2001 and have two children--one son and one daughter. Both of them are still young. The family lives in a small village across the Mekong River approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.
 
Sothea has been a bicycle and motorbike repairer for ten years. He operates the business in his village. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. Sothea is asking for his first loan in the amount of US$ 1,000. He will use $500 of the loan to purchase motorcycle spare part for his business and another $500 to buy a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle spare part for his business and buy a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Reuben Gitau

texts.en:
Reuben has been delivering fruit to his clients on order and also walking round town looking for new customers.  He has been doing this in Naivasha town since the year 2000.   He is 32 years old, married to Mercy Nduta, and they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 3rd loan.  He has serviced his previous loans well and on time.  He plans to use the loan to build a kiosk in town where he will operate his business from.  

Reuben is also hoping to buy a truck which he will use for large deliveries that he has to make.

loans.use: To build a kiosk to operate from

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina V. is from the village of Brgy. Abinganan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 53 years old. Saturnina is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Saturnina owns & operates a business venture in the food sector. The main source of income for the business comes from selling fruits and vegetables to the local community. Saturnina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Saturnina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Saturnina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Saturnina is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Saturnina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Rana

texts.en:
Miss Rana N. (in the photo with her widowed mother), is single and lives with her mother, sisters, and brothers in a village along National Road Number One, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her mother is farmer. 

Rana is a teacher and a tailor. One of her brothers is learning tailoring, so she is asking for her second loan of US$ 500 to pay fees for her brother. She will also use a part of her loan to help capitalize her mother's farming business.

loans.use: To pay fees for her brother who is learning tailoring  and help capital her mother’s farming business

loans.name: Vun

texts.en:
Mrs. Vun H. and her husband, Mr. Den Yem, have been married since 1970 and have three children--one son and two daughters. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Vun H. used to be a silk weaver, but she stopped weaving and transferred her looms to her daughters. Mr. Den Yem is a farmer and raises cows at their home. 

Vun asked for a Kiva loan one time already. She now is requesting another loan in the amount of US$ 1,000 to buy silk materials for her daughter’s weaving business. 

Photo: Mrs. Vun H. with the loom.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her daughter’s weaving business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 23-year-old single man living with his mother and 3 brothers. After the death of his father, he started working together with his brothers to satisfy the needs of the family. He started his business  in car painting in 2007. This young man works hard to earn income and improve his life situation. During those two years, his work operation has become bigger and he has gained a good number of clients. Today, he has the opportunity to develop and expand his business into other areas and attract more clients. To do so, he is requesting to borrow US$ 1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase painting supplies at a good price.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free Kiva loans  to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. loans.name: Mr. Sa Mon Prum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has eleven people who live in Chek village, Takeo province. Mr. Sa Mon P. is a village bank president who was born in 1960. He was selected by the other members, who will use their portion of their loan for different purposes. 

He and his wife, Mrs. Tem Koum, are farmers who own more than a 1-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. He is a vice village chief, while his wife is a Khmer cake and congee seller. 

His problem is that his field has infertile soil. So to improve rice production, Mr. Sa Mon P. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline. He is a father of four children, one of whom is a farmer, while the others are studying in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarom C. and her husband, Mr. Kimseng Chour, have been married since 1986 and have nine children--two sons and seven daughters. Six of them are married and live outside the family home and other three are in school. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sarom is a silk weaver. She is older but she is still strong enough to work. She is asking for a loan of US$ 200 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon G. is from the village of Punit. She is 32 years old. Corazon is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Corazon owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Corazon has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP when she sells her raised animals.

In 2009, Corazon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Corazon from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Bunneang

texts.en:
Mrs. Bunneang K. (pictured here), is 46 years old and her husband, Mr. Ngoun Men, also 48 years old, live in a village along National Road Number two approximately thirteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1985 and have four children, two sons and two daughters. Two of them have full time employment and other two children are in school. 

Bunneang sells roast beef, and sandwiches on baguettes from her home. Her husband is a taxi driver. She is requesting a loan in the amount of US $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 37-year old single woman living with her parents in Lebanon. She has 15 years of experience working as a farmer. She has been running her own farm since 2001. She uses plastic tents to grow her products. These tents also allow her to better monitor product quality as well as grow her products for more months during the year. She cultivates all type of vegetables and fruits all through the year. She works independently in her business. 

Today, she is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for her agricultural work and seeds for the next cultivation. She estimates that the loan will help her increase her profits by 20%. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies for her agricultural work and seeds for planting

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma P. is from the village of Capayangan, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 45 years old. Gemma is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gemma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Gemma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mrs. Sareth Sa Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Ten people who all live in Chek village, Takeo province, have selected Mrs. Sareth S. as this village bank president. She was born in 1969. Each member will use their portion of their loan in varied ways to support their businesses. 

Mrs. Sareth S. is a pork and fish seller at her local market, where she can earn a large profit to support her family while her husband, Mr. Voeurn Hen, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. So to improve her business, Mrs. Sareth S. is applying for a loan to buy more vegetables and pork to resale. 

She is a mother of two children, both of whom are attending school.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and pork to resale

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Mr. Leng K. (in the photo), is 49 year-old and his wife, Mrs. Sarin Chea, is 49 year-old, have been married since 1980 and have seven children, one son and six daughters. Two of the children are garment factory workers. The other two assist their mother with the farming business and three children are in school. The family lives in a village along National Road Number One, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Leng is a chef. He cooks for wedding parties and other ceremonies. His wife is a farmer; she grows cauliflowers and green beans. In addition, Leng hopes to supplement their income with a new business by raising fish. He does not, however, have sufficient start-up capital. Therefore, he is applying for his first loan in the amount of $1,000 in order to launch the business.

loans.use: To use for raising fish.

loans.name: Sarah Joy

texts.en:
Sarah Joy P. is from the village of Pinamulan, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 26 years old. Sarah Joy is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Sarah Joy owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Sarah Joy has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sarah Joy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sarah Joy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Sarah Joy is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Sarah Joy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old married man with one child from Lebanon. He has been working in the jewelry business for the past 23 years. He started his own business in 1991.  He works on a freelance basis, upon request of the clients, who have the option to choose any design from special catalogs. He also works for a local jewelry shops in his town.  

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.al.  to invest in more materials for his work. He remains optimistic about the future and hopes to one day to open his own jewelry store and build a name for himself in this field. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

loans.name: 02.02.13 Thieu Hoa Group

texts.en:
"Doan N. T. (50) is a 47 year-old woman living in the town of T. Hoa - Thanh Hoa.  Doan is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 13  T. hoa (02.02.13 T. hoa).

Doan is married and has 3 adult aged children.  To making a living, Doan operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising cattle for sale.  Doan has been engaged in this business for over 19 years and earns approximately 1.200.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2003, Doan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Doan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.248.000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase young livestock to raise & sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will be used to purchase young livestock to raise & sell in future.  The loan will be the 6th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Doan plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  T. T. Mai (49) is a 40 year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

2.  N. T. Luan (35) is a 56 year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

3.  T. T. Linh (17) is a 24 year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

4.  N. T. Len (51) is a 49 year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

loans.name: Riskan

texts.en:
Riskan O. is 53 years old and has four children: one daughter (who is married and lives away from home) and three sons – the youngest of whom helps her on the farm.
Riskan graduated from college and worked as a typist, but it was not a very profitable activity and additional earnings were required in order to support her family. That’s why, in 1993, Riskan started a business breeding cattle and cultivating kidney beans and perennial herbs. Using her capital of 55,000 KGS, Riskan bought dairy cows and sowed her land. Being a very active person, she was able to lease a plot of land for five years outside of her “The first May” village. Riskan and her family worked hard to get a good harvest. Selling dairy products and kidney beans has allowed Riskan to buy a car for her family.
Riskan plans to use this loan of 70,000 KGS to enlarge her number of dairy cows and purchase mineral fertilizers that will lead to increased crop production and top-quality products. In the future, Riskan plans to help her son to buy a house in the village.

About Bai-Tushun
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 36 year old single man from Lebanon. He lives alone. He has 7 years of experience working with mobile phones. He began as an employee in a mobile shop and opened his own store in 2003. With his loan requested of US $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will be able to increase his merchandise selection of new mobile phones and purchase prepaid telephone cards to sell. The majority of mobile phone users in Lebanon purchase these prepaid cards; it is less common to have an annual phone contract as is common in many Western countries. He reports that both his income and business productivity will be increased as a result of the loan. In the future, he is looking to further expand his business and increase his capital. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To increase his selection of new mobile phones and purchase prepaid telephone cards to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a single mother of four children and all of them are at school. She takes care of additional family members. She owns a  liquor store in Nakulabye, selling local gin, and has been in this bar business for five years. Rose buys jerrycans of local gin from suppliers who get it from villages and so doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work.

She plans to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of local gin. She sells to all categories of people, but wholesale only. She works twice a week and besides this local gin business, she also sells piped water. She depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges are seasonality and defaulters.

Rose decided to join MCDT because of low interest rates and because of being trustworthy. She aspires to seeing her business grow big and be able to start going directly to producers, and also to educate her children through university. She resides in and rents a two roomed house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and rent

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of local gin to sell.

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
Pilar G. is from the village of Bolinao. She is 43 years old. Pilar is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Pilar owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Pilar has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Pilar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pilar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Pilar is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Pilar from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

To make a living, Marlyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. loans.name: Zarina's Group

texts.en:
Zarina is a resident of Multan, which is the famous city of Pakistan for its sweetmeat and warm weather. She is 45 years old and financially supports her family by doing embroidery works. She lives in a three room brick house with her family. She has been living in it for the last ten years. Her husband is a loader by trade. He uses his donkey cart to load different items and to deliver it to designated places.

She is the mother of two daughters and a son. Her son also helps her in her embroidery business, while her daughters are too young to attend to school. He learned the art of embroidery from her and now he not only helps her in completing the larger orders on time, but also helps her to deliver the dresses to the concerned persons.

Zarina has applied for a loan from Asasah for her embroidery business With the loan amount she will expand her business by buying embroidery materials such as beads, colored thread and clothes in bulk.

This is the first time she has applied for a loan from any MFI. She hopes that her decision will be fruitful for her business.

loans.use: To purchase embroidery materials in bulk.

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 36 year old married woman from Lebanon. She has been working as a beautician for the past 13 years from her home. She offers all the beauty services to her customers such as make-up, pedicure manicure, tattoo, etc. Her income is very important for her family and to support her husband who is working out of Lebanon to earn the needed income for his family. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a tattoo machine instead of renting one. In the future, she would like to open a formal beauty salon for women. Mercedes O. is from the village of Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 59 years old, widowed, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Mercedes owns and operates a retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste from a direct-selling company in the local community. loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 47-year-old married man and father of three school-aged children. He is from Lebanon and has been working as an experienced car seller for the past eight years. His business consists of buying cars, making the needed maintenance, and reselling them to make a profit. He is thankful for his business income as it helps him to satisfy his heavy expenses and pay for his children's schooling. He offers his customers all types of car and also works on customer request. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l., to perform maintenance on some cars so that he can sell them as soon as possible and make a good profit from them. In the future, he hopes that he will be able to open a used car shop.

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran is a resident of the historic city known as Multan. Multan is a very old city known for its tombs and hot weather. She lives in a small house with her husband and five children. Her husband operates a business of making and selling bed sheets, while her eldest son also helps him in his business. 

Sugran belongs to a poor family, due to which she couldn’t manage to give an education to her children. She operates a business of embroidery. She is very good in her art and has been doing this business for over eight years. She collects orders from her neighborhood clients and fulfills them on time. She is very famous for her embroidery works and gets regular orders.

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her embroidery business. With the loan amount she will buy an embroidery machine, which will help her to finish the orders on time and in improve her business.

This is her first loan cycle with an MFI and she hopes that she will be able to improve her business and that will help in the marriage of her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase an embroidery machine.

loans.name: Aisaada's Group

texts.en:
Aisaada S. is the leader of this group. She is 33 and divorced. She has a seven-year-old daughter in school. Four years ago, with the initial investment of 7000 soms, Aisaada rented some land and began to cultivate strawberries. Selling the strawberries she makes 10000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase a cow. Now she wants a loan to continue her business activity. In the future Aisaada plans to purchase a house and save money to pay for her daughter’s education.

Kymbat K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 30 and divorced. She has a son in school. A year ago Kymbat, took money from her relatives, purchased fruit and vegetables, and then resold them at a higher price. She started with an initial investment of 15000 soms and made a profit of 15000 soms. With the loan, Kymbat wants to purchase more fruit and vegetables to resell and make some money. In the future Kymbat wants to open her own grocery store.

Madi S. is 20. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 13000 soms, he started to cultivate strawberries. He made good profit and that profit made it possible for him to purchase twenty sheep for breeding. With money received from the loan, Madi wants to hire labor, which he needs for cultivating strawberries. In the future he plans to get married and then purchase a vehicle.

Raikan C., 50, is a widow. She has raised a son and a daughter; the son works as a security guard and the daughter is married and lives in Kazakhstan with her family. Raikan works in the public hospital. She applied for the loan because she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase household appliances. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en: Teddy is married with six children, all of them in school, and also takes care of additional family members. She owns a bar in Nakulabye selling local brew. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerycans of local brew and local gin. She has been in this business for ten years. She also has a restaurant and sells to all categories of people. Teddy works six days a week and depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges are defaulters and the rainy season. She hopes to see her business grow big and start selling wholesale only. She lives in, and owns, a three-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses are school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more jerycans of local brew and local gin

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 39-year-old single man living with his parents. He is the main income provider for his family. He has 20 years of experience working as a mechanic and has run his own car repair shop since 2008. This man is very supportive of his parents and always tries to take care of them. He is specialized in repairing car bodies. Today, he is requesting $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional tools for his business. The tools are necessary to expand his business and handle more clients. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: to purchase tools

loans.name: Jemelia

texts.en:
Jemelia B. is from the village of Poblacion, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 43 and married with three school-aged children. Jemelia has a store selling products including dried fish and shrimp. Jemelia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Jemelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase additional dried fish to sell. Jemelia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 12th loan taken out by Jemelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn M. is from the village of Diaz, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 32 years old. Marilyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for her business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Marilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Marilyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
Nazia lives in a one-room brick house in a historic city called Multan. Multan city is famous for its history and hot weather. 

She is a 30-year-old lady who got married at an early age. She is a mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her two elder children are getting their education while the younger ones are too young to attend to school. 

Her husband sells clothes. He purchases clothes from Faisalabad, and from their native city as well, and sells them at the local market and to rich families of the city. He has 20 years of experience in this business. He doesn’t has a shop to display the variety of clothes, but he goes to different areas on his bicycle and announces his products in a loud voice to attract people to his clothes collection. 

Nazia helps her husband financially by doing embroidery works. She has good contacts and a customer base so she receives regular orders.
 
Nazia has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy clothes in bulk. This will not only help him in cost reduction but also enable him to offer more variety to his customers. 

Nazia is a new loan user and this is her first loan cycle. She hopes this will be a good experience for her and her family as well.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for reselling

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida K. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, green vegetables and dried fish. She is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish to sell.  

Vida is 31 years old and married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

loans.use: Stock more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn S., from the village of Liwayway, Banisilan, Cotabato, is 44 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a service-based business providing wedding services and the renting of wedding dresses to local community members. Engaged in her enterprise for over five years, she earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that used to purchase materials needed to provide service, she is now requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to invest in renovating the business. This will be Jocelyn's second loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in renovating the business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 27 years old. Josephine is married. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita N. is from the village of Mother Katutungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 42 years old. Nenita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Nenita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Nenita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Waefeso Group

texts.en:
Jane U., age 44, is married with 4 children, ages, 28, 25, 22 and 20 years. She has had a poultry business since 1998 and also has been selling cement since 2001.  She works daily from 5am until 3pm and she is able to earn a monthly profit of around $1307. This will be Jane’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  With the loan she plans to buy more sacks of cements. She is a hard working lady.

Jane will share this loan with her loan group, Waefeso, which totals 16 members. The members of the group hold each other responsible in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Jane is wearing a pink dress standing in the second row.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of cement.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bejing Group

texts.en:
Regina E., age 28, is married with two children, who are 7 and 11 years old. She has had a business of selling fruits and vegetables for two and a half years. She works from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. and she is able to earn a monthly profit of about $197.

This will be Regina’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to buy more fruits and vegetables and she has successfully paid back the loan. 

She hopes for a new loan to expand her business by adding more stock of fruits and vegetables. Regina’s future dreams include opening another fruit and vegetable place.

Regina will share this loan with her loan group, Bejing, which totals 19 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture,  Regina is standing in the center, wearing a red and white dress.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rejoice

texts.en: Rejoice W. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and baking flour in her shop. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and beans to sell.  Rejoice is 41 years old and married to a laborer. She has 4 children, who all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to stock bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
Elmira S., 45, is the leader of this group. She is a widow and has raised four children. Elmira’s mother-in-law suggested that she purchase a cow and sell milk to make money. Elmira now sells ten liters of milk per day. She also breeds livestock and wants to use the money received from this loan to purchase sheep for breeding. In the future, Elmira plans to increase the number of her livestock and to save money to be able to support her children in the future.

Kenjeke M. is the treasurer of the group. She is 35 and a widow. She has three children; all of them are at school. Kenjeke is engaged in farming, cultivating barley and clover. She also sells 15 liters of milk every day, earning 5,000 KGS per month. With the money received from this loan, Kenjeke wants to purchase saltpeter which is needed for farming. In the future, she wants to save money to be able to give her children a good education.

Elvira A., 37, is married. She has three children; all of them are at school. Elvira and her husband are farmers, cultivating barley and various fruits and vegetables and breeding cattle. To make money, Elvira sells milk (10 liters per day). Elvira makes 10,000 KGS per month from all these activities. With the money received from this loan, she wants to purchase a calf to increase the number of her cattle. In the future, Elvira plans to purchase a vehicle.

Syrga BeishenA., 50, is a widow. She has raised four children; three of them are married and live separately with their families. The youngest daughter lives with her mom and studies at school. Syrga has been engaged in cattle breeding for 25 years. To make money, Syrga sells milk (10 liters per day), earning 2,400 KGS per month. She applied for this loan because she needs money to purchase feed for cattle for the winter season. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Jeep Group

texts.en:
Bitrosy C., 23 years old, is single. He has operated a business selling tomatoes for 5 years. He is really a hardworking young boy. He travels upcountry to collect and buy tomatoes and then sells them in different markets in the city center.  He works from 5 a.m. to 6 p.m. and is able to make a monthly profit of about $197.

This will be Bitrosy’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He  hopes for a loan so that he may travel further for a good stock of tomatoes for his business. Bitrosy will share this loan with his loan group, Jeep. The 16 members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 
	
In the picture, Bitrosy is 3rd from the left in the front row, wearing a fabric shirt.

loans.use: To buy more stock of tomatoes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is married with four children and all of them are at school. She also takes care of an additional family member, her sister. 

She owns a retail shop in Nabulagala, selling all types of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, biscuits, dry cells, books and utensils. She buys merchandise from Kikuubo in Kampala once a week and uses public transport to and from buying her goods. 

She sells to all categories of people, but on a retail basis. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise, like bags of sugar, cartons of salt, jerrycans of cooking oil and boxes of soap.  

Besides this retail shop business, she carries out tailoring as an additional source of livelihood. She has been in this business for the last five years. She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living. 

Her major business challenge is the rainy season, which hinders her customers' ability to reach her because she works in a muddy place.  

She aspires to see her business grow and to get enough profits to buy her own house. She decided to join MCDT because of good customer care.   

She resides in and rents a two-roomed house, which has electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent for both her residence and business, and food.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise, like bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerrycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Janylbu's Group

texts.en: Janylbu A. is the leader of the group. She is 54 and a widow. She has raised two sons and two daughters. The older daughter works in Russia, the second daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the first son is a constructor and the second serves in the army. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, Janylbu started to sell corn. She makes 5000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to improve their living conditions. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase corn in order to resell it at a higher price. In the future, Janylbu plans to expand her business and open a sales point in Bishkek. Eliza K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 31 and married. She has a son and two daughters, all of whom are at school. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, Eliza opened a kiosk near her house and started to sell convenience goods. She makes 6000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the near future, Eliza plans to purchase a vehicle. Duriyakan N., 52, is a widow. She has raised two sons and two daughters, all of whom are married and live separately with their families. In 1995, Duriyakan started to breed cattle and then she began to resell the cattle on the animal market. She made good money and since that moment, Duriyakan has been breeding cattle and reselling them after fattening. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase cattle in order to resell them, after fattening, at a higher price. Bulbulkan K., 46, is married. She has two sons and three daughters. Her younger son and the younger daughter are at school and the other children are married. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, Bulbulkan started to take orders and sew national clothing from dressmaking supplies. In this way, she makes 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a sewing machine. In the near future, she plans to open her own sewing workshop. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

The borrower is well-known in his town and all the clients ask for his services and they feel comfortable with him. He has taken a first loan from Ameen s.a.l. and has been very punctual with his repayments. Today, he is asking for his second loan of $300 to purchase merchandise such as shampoo, wax, gel, etc., to be always ready for his customers. loans.name: Koryun

texts.en:
Koryun lives with his family of seven on the outskirts of Yerevan city. He opened a small grocery shop in front of their home in 1998. He is the only breadwinner in his family and takes care of his parents, wife and children. 

To expand his business and to meet the local community’s demand, Koryun has applied for the loan to purchase small household appliances.

loans.use: Purchasing small household appliances

loans.name: Ainura

texts.en: Ainura M. is a resident of Tup, a small town in the Isykul region. She is 45 and married. She has two daughters and a son. The son studies at school and the daughters live in Bishkek. The first daughter is a teacher at a university and the second works in a pharmacy. In 1994, because of the high unemployment rate, Ainura and her husband began to sell potatoes to make money. Now they have their own container and sell flour there. Ainura also began to sell garlic. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase 500 kg of garlic in order to resell it at a higher price in the winter. In the future, she plans to start building a house, purchase a minibus and save some money to contribute to her daughter’s wedding. Where Did This Loan Come From? loans.name: Vardan

texts.en:
Vardan S. has won a kickboxing champion’s title on multiple occasions. This well-known kickboxing trainer received a trauma after which he was unable to continue his active involvement in martial arts. Vardan started his business in 2003, selling computer accessories and discs. He takes care of his pensioner mother. 

Vardan is planning to extend his business by introducing program discs and more computer accessories in his shop.

loans.use: purchasing program discs and computer accessories

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and two brothers. He has been working as an experienced hairdresser for the past fifteen years. In addition to his shop operation, he also offers his beauty services upon request to the clients at their homes. He always tries to be up to date in this market and offers the new hair designs to his customers. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from the Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase new hairdressing tools for his work. In the future, he would like to expand his client base and he hopes to open a bigger beauty salon.

loans.name: Suren

texts.en: Suren O. has a family of six. He has been managing a flower shop since 2000. Apart from flowers, the shop also trades in plants.  Anticipating a very busy September month when the school season opens, Suren has applied for a loan to purchase plants.

loans.use: purchasing plants

loans.name: Seda

texts.en: Seda B. has a family of ten. She and her daughter are the main financial supporters.  Seda has been managing her clothing business since 1999  and has applied for the loan to purchase new clothing stock. While she manages the business, her daughter will travel to the neighboring country to purchase the clothing.

loans.use: renewing the clothing stock

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine I. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol at home and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer to sell.  She is 42 years old and her husband is a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar at the market.

loans.use: Stock crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Badegna I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Badegna I sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans, en moyenne 3 enfants et qui vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygames à Maban, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le petit mil, l’arachide, le fonio et le haricot. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, ARATA D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare de petit mil, d’arachide et du fonio.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50 000FCFA environ par campagne.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the group Badgena I are married women with an average age of 42 years, an average of 3 children, and most of them live in polygamous families in Maban, one of the villages in the Dioïla prefecture, in the Koulikoro region, the second administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their activities during the rainy season. They grow, among other things, pearl millet, peanuts, fonio, and beans. This will be their sixth seasonal loan and all of their previous loans have been fully repaid. With this new loan, Arata D. hopes to buy fertilizer, small farming equipment, and pay for labor costs to maintain about 1 hectare of pearl millet, peanuts, and folio. The harvested crops are sold in the towns of Dioïla and Massigui to a client base composed of both men and women. The women hope to make an average profit of 50,000 francs CFA per season.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, and small farming equipment

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity G. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables such as dodo (amaranth greens), okra, etc. at the market and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish and jerrycans of cooking oil to sell.  Charity is 49 years old and is a widow.   She has seven children and none of them go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.use: Stock dried fish and jerrycans of cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Badegna  Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe Badegna II sont des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Maban, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le petit mil, l’arachide, le fonio, le haricot et le sésame. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, SATA D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environ 1 hectare de petit mil, d’arachide et de sésame.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 60.000FCFA environ par campagne.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Badegna II group are married women with an average age of 37 and 3 children each. Most of them live in polygamous families in Maban, one of the villages of the prefecture of Dioïla, Koulikoro region, 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to better organize their activities at the beginning of the rainy season. The crops cultivated are, among others, pearl millet, peanuts, fonio ( a type of millet), beans and sesame. This is their sixth planting loan and all previous loans have been fully repaid. With this new loan, SATA D. plans to pay for planting supplies, small agricultural tools and ploughing costs to maintain approximately 1 hectare of pearl millet, peanuts and sesame. The crops are sold in the towns of Dioïla and Massigui after the harvest to a clientele composed of men and women. They expect to make an average profit of around 60,000 CFA per planting.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ploughing, planting supplies and small agricultural tools

loans.name: Keji

texts.en: Keji L. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and firewood at her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Keji is 40 years old and is married to a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a charcoal store at the market.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Badegan Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Badegna III sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 3 enfants et  vivant dans des familles polygames à Maban, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées  par ce groupe sont le petit mil, l’arachide, le fonio et le haricot. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, AWA LASSENI D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1, 3 hectare de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée essentiellement de revendeurs.
 Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50.000FCFA environ par campagne.
texts.en:
The members of the Badegna III group are married women with an average age of 40 and an average of three children. They live in polygamous families in Maban, a village in the Dioïla prefecture in the Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of Mali). They are working with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their activities in the beginning of the rainy season. The crops grown by this group include pearl millet, peanuts, millet, and beans. They are on their sixth loan, and all previous loans have been fully repaid. With this new loan, Awa Lasseni Dembélé plans to buy fertilizers and small farming equipment and to pay for labor costs to maintain about 1.3 hectares of pearl millet and peanuts. Their crops are sold in the city of Dioïla after harvest to a clientele made up mostly of resellers. They expect to make an average profit of 50,000FCFA per planting season.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Plowing, fertilizers, and small farming equipment

loans.name: Benkadi  I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Benkadi I sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Wobougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont le riz, le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, ALIMATA T., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environ 1, 6 hectare d’arachide et de haricot.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de consommateurs et de revendeurs. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 70.000FCFA environ par campagne.
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi I  portent tout leur espoir sur le bon déroulement de la campagne hivernale.
texts.en:
